WRITING.TITLE: It's true
Does anyone find Hermione #8217;s schedual in Prisoner of Azkaban weird?
WRITING.TEXT: Why does Hogwarts make a student use a time-turner instead of making a schedual where every student can theoretically make it to every class? What if someone really wants to take Arithmancy and Care of Magical Creatures, but they #8217;re both at 9 a.m.?

Thanks! I was just thinking how I also had to choose in college between different classes, but they lasted one term and at the end of the day weren #8217;t that important for my overall education... And there weren #8217;t many instances when I had to make a choice like that... But it seems how in Hogwarts they make a choice in their second year which will influence their whole education, and their future careers, which isn #8217;t easy, and then they just make it more difficult for students to choose by making them pick only one class between the three that all take place at the same time. It #8217;s just someting that bothers me because I #8217;d probably pull a Hermione and choose everything because they all seem really interesting

I could be wrong here, but isn #8217;t there a passage in the Chamber of Secrets where they talk about choosing classes for their third year, and how it affects their future careers? And then signing up for different classes? I know Percy and Hermione were really interested in that, and Ron and Harry didn #8217;t put much though into it.

That #8217;s an interesting point, how some subjects are not commonly taken together, and thefore scheduals are made with that though in mind. It #8217;s just that I #8217;m really against making children decide their educational path at such a young age. I think it #8217;s ok when you #8217;re twelve to be interested in Muggle studies and Arithmancy at the same time, even though maybe those subjects are not commonly taken together. At that age you #8217;re still under the influence of your family, society etc and it just seems like too big of a commitment to just choose one path and then stick to it. But their time spent in school is pretty short, so I #8217;m probably reading too much into this. That being said, I 100% agree with you that she could have taken extra time for homework and sleep, it #8217;s still for the purpose of her taking every class possible, so she shouldn #8217;t have felt guilty or anything.

WRITING.TITLE: What is your favourite Ron moment?
WRITING.TEXT: Mine is probably in PoA when, during Potions, he threw a crocodile heart and hit Malfoy in the face, causing Gryffindor to lose 50 point. Seeing how that was only a week after he got a detention for defending Hermione after Snape insulted her, it showed real bravery.
One could argue that in order to be brave you have to be, at least to some extent, reckless
Oscar and Kevin's jail talk

WRITING.TITLE: Dwight Danger Schrute

WRITING.TEXT: Yeah you #8217;re right. They sometimes go hand in hand but not always. However, I think they almost always overlap when it comes to standing up to authority figures, which is what my example is about. I mean, there is really no reason to stand up to someone like Snape, you #8217;ll lose a bunch of points, get detention etc. So really Ron was being super reckless. But Malfoy was making fun of his best friend almost dying on the pitch, and Snape made his other best friend cry and he humiliated her in front of the whole class, so Ron wasn #8217;t thinking about himself, he defended them. So that was both brave and reckless. Same thing goes with Harry shouting at Umbridge. Was that reckless? Yes. Was it brave? Definitely.

WRITING.TITLE: Daring today, aren't we?

WRITING.TEXT: Yes!!! What #8217;s worse, I think they gave that line (if you want to kill Harry you #8217;ll have to kill us too) to Hermione, which is yet another example of how movies ruined Ron #8217;s character. In the movies he just cries in the background because his leg is broken.

Me too, but I walk a lot (almost every week I get the 50 km reward) and I hatch about 3-4 10 km eggs a week. And I only got gibble once. The most common ones that I do get are dratini, larvitar, beldum, and I have plenty of those. Needless to say, I stopped caring about 10 km eggs because they #8217;re usually soooo disappointing.

He #8217;s really good at reading the mood of the conversation and has a great social intelligence. I don #8217;t think it necessarily makes him a legilimens. And also, I was under the impression that legilimency required eye contact and some form of violent penetration into another person #8217;s mind? Because in The Half Blood Prince, when Snape tries to #8220;read #8221; Malfoys mind, Malfoy says something like #8220;I know what you #8217;re doing I won #8217;t let you #8221; and then Snape says something like #8220;Bellatrix taught you well #8221; or something. Because of that, I always thought that a person cannot have their mind penetrated without knowing it, idk.
She just conjures the food that already exists but is somewhere else, for example in the cellar, or a in a different bowl.
That #8217;s really interesting, do you have any examples maybe?

I never saw it that way. Dumbledore is over a hundred years old, and he #8217; probably one of the most intelligent people in the world, who isn #8217;t easily fooled. I don #8217;t think he needs legilimency to tell if a teenage boy, whose emotions are not easily concealed, is lying to him. He has a penetrating stare that feels like an x-ray, but that is just a characteristic, a part of his personality, not him reading someone #8217;s mind. Also, while that is not explicitly said, legilimency has strong connections to dark magic. Most famous legilimens are Voldemort, Salazar Slytherin and Snape. While Dumbledore is a legilimens as well, I don #8217;t think he would use legilimency lightly, especially not on a student. It #8217;s an extreme violation of a person #8217;s privacy, and is, at the end of the day, immoral. It is enough to say that legilimency is something Voldemort *enjoys* doing. So it is a bit twisted. The only two instances we know Dumbledore to use legilimency is to interrogate Kreacher and Voldemort #8217;s uncle. I wouldn #8217;t go that far to say that he ever performed it on Harry, or any student for that matter.

WRITING.TITLE: Yes, I am
Well that's awkward

WRITING.TEXT: This is maybe an unpopular opinion, but Lily and James. They loved each other so much, even though she hated him when they were kids. People change and mature over time, and so did James, and just the fact that he loved Lily all his life and then she started seeing something in him is beautiful. Also, scenes of their lives before Voldemort kills them, with Lily and James casually playing with Harry in the living room, and then Harry finding out from Lily #8217;s letter just how happy they were, are heart-breaking. James is a much better fit for Lily than Snape could ever be.

WRITING.TITLE: TIL that tickle torture was used in ancient Rome, where a person #8217;s feet were dipped in a salt solution, and a goat was brought in to lick the solution off. This type of tickle torture would only start as tickling, eventually becoming extremely painful.

WRITING.TEXT: Interesting question. Given that Harry #8217;s cloak is one of a kind, that provides complete protection, it would probably protect him from legilimency, even if it doesn #8217;t require eye contact (which I think it does). It #8217;s not an ordinary invisibility cloak. The explanation here is probably that Snape assumes that Harry is behind any rule-breaking in Hogwarts. Especially because he knows that Harry has the cloak, but also because, in this example, Harry left an egg behing, and only 4 students at that time had the egg.

They probably did need to catch up on spells after spending so many years in prison, but since they were all fully qualified wizards, I don #8217;t think it was a big problem. The one example from the books that I can think of that relates to your question is in the Half Blood Prince when Hagrid forgot which spell to use when his cabin was on fire. He asked Harry how to produce water, and when he remembered the spell he had no trouble producing it. So I assume that if they do forget something it #8217;s the incantation, which is understandable because there is a lot of them. But if they become competent in one spell they will catch up quickly no matter how much time had passed.
Half Blood Prince Order of Phoenix Deathly Hallows Prisoner of Azkaban Goblet of Fire Chamber of Secrets Philosopher #8217;s Stone

Me too. I guess it #8217;s the same thing as Harry not being able to see testrals at the end of GoF. It didn #8217;t make sense to introduce it so early on for the sake of the plot, but there #8217;s really no magical explanation for it.
God, I think they #8217;d be so angry Dedalus would have to Obliviate all three of them.

WRITING.TITLE: Consult with your doctor before using

WRITING.TEXT: Kevin is a national treasure.

I agree, it #8217;s probably seeing Lupin dead. Maybe even Moody #8217;s corpse could be a boggart for a younger Tonks, given how he was her mentor and how the two of them had a special bond. His death really affected her in the Deathly Hallows.

WRITING.TITLE: What are the biggest misconceptions about the HP Universe in your opinion?
WRITING.TEXT: So basically, anything you hear about the books that is completely wrong and annoys you? For example, I really hate it when people are being dismissive about Voldemort #8217;s powers and think Voldemort is this neurotic wizard who can #8217;t do anything right and fails to murder Harry every year at the end of his school year. I don #8217;t think people fully realize how powerful he is, and how dangerous it is to be around him. This has a lot to do with, in my opinion, really bad portayal of Voldemort in the movies. I love Ralp Fiennes, but I don #8217;t think he captured the essence of Voldemort. Some of his scenes are so over the top, when he yells like a maniac, like Dumbledore and the infamous #8220;did you put your name in the Goblet of Fire? #8221; It seems like the only spell he knows is Avada Kedavra which usually clashes with Harry #8217;s Expelliarmus and achieves nothing.

Harry is really underrated. He was only twelve when he defeated a Basilisk for example, and people still think he just gets lucky every time. Ron too, they mutilated his character in the movies. I guess movies are to blame for most misconceptions. They #8217;re just too bad.

Yeah, I think people took it too seriously. I mean, Harry went through a process of realizing that his father was flawed but all in all a good man. We all go through that as we get older, we stop idolizing our parents. So Harry, who until then only heard about his father being an amazing seeker, a Head Boy, a talented animagus, saw a memory where all of that made him arrogant. It #8217;s just a realization that nobody #8217;s perfect. But people read that as James being a horrible person.

That #8217;s a good point, people underestimating Death Eaters. Yes, Lucius Malfoy proved himself to be incompetent and disinclined to follow Voldemort all the way. But the rest of them are just evil. I always saw them as Hitler #8217;s inner circle, who #8217;s just as bad as him. So to have a Dark Mark tattooed means that you #8217;re either extremely ignorant or a horrible person.

The first books is a good example of this. The plot doesn #8217;t really affect the plot of the rest of the series, and things like the philosopher #8217;s stone are never mentioned again. But of course, that #8217;s understandable, it #8217;s just that the first book is my least favourite one precisely because of that.

I totally agree, I just can #8217;t see why people automatically assume someone #8217;s an introvert just because they like to read. I know loads of introverts who hate reading and studying. And also extroverts who read all the time. I guess movies and tv shows that deal with young adults like to show someone #8217;s shy and introverted by giving them a book to read. And glasses. I #8217;m surprised Harry #8217;s not labeled an introvert because he #8217;s wearing them.

I know, I always get mad when in the CoS movies Malfoy calls Hermione a mudblood and then she explains what a mudblood is. Come on, they could have at least given Ron that line given that he provides information about the wizarding world in the books. But no, they even took that away from him. As if it wasn #8217;t enough that they made him so much dumber.

This is really important for people to understand. But I guess for movies reasons they wanted to make it as if Buckbeack was killed and then they saved him in an alternate timeline, to increase the suspension. But what they did in the Cursed Child with the time turner is unforgivable. That #8217;s just completely destroying everything that made sense in the PoA.

I always wondered whose idea it was to portray Dumbledore that way. No glasses, no silver hair, no crazy colours, no peaceful calm voice. In the movies he seems like a wizard who loses its temper and knows he is in a position of power and acts like it. Book Dubledore is just a completely different person.
Dammit Kevin

Well, I only know about Grindelwald from what I read in the 7 HP books because I haven #8217;t seen Crimes of Grindelwald (I have trouble forcing myself to care about those movies tbh). So I might be completely wrong here. But, we know that Grindelwald never had a strong following in Britain because he was afraid of Dumbledore. He was the strongest in Eastern Europe. Voldemort saw himself as being superior in every way possible, and was the proudest because of his Salazar Slytherin heritage. I wouldn #8217;t be surprised he though his nationality was the purest as well. If he is the wizard equivalent of Hitler, then I guess Grindelwald would be Stalin. Knowing how those two functioned together, I wouldn #8217;t be surprised if the same would work with Voldemort and Grindelwald. So that would mean that Voldemort would first let Grindelwald do its thing and support him for some time, but seeing himself superior in every way he would eventually get rid of him. One of Voldemort #8217;s problems is that he wanted to do everything by himself, and only recognized a small number of people fit enough to follow him. So in a situation where Voldemort and Grindewald interact, it wouldn #8217;t have lasted long.

WRITING.TITLE: What the UN is all about?

WRITING.TEXT: UN: At least I tried.

Well, he would definitely used Grindelwald just as he used the Ministry for Magic to spread his power. So he wouldn #8217;t phisically attend meetings or anything, but would use either his men or someone under Imperius curse to work for his benefit. But like I said, I don #8217;t think Voldemort would keep up with that for too long, Grindelwald was too powerful, a competition. He would have tried to kill him before long. Voldemort works alone.

Sirius. I love it how he never even considered to fit in his family and though all the pure blood talk was rubbish. He was also a great friend, and an extremely intelligent person. To think that his life was ruined by staying for 12 years in Azkaban, only to finally escape and die just before he had the opportunity to clear his name always makes me sad.

No, he taught Transfiguration before he became the Headmaster. His work was always academic, he never worked for the Ministry.

I only recognize the 7 books as canon, my bad. I know I #8217;m not supposed to, given that JK wrote Fantastic Beasts. But that whole expansion of the universe really lacks something magical that only books have, and I can #8217;t make myself care about it.

I think this could only be explained as a plot hole. Sirius is pretty tall, and he didn #8217;t need to crawl. I doubt 17-year-old Harry was taller than Sirius. I think the point was to emphasise how much time has passed, and how they were children in PoA and now they are adults. But it is still an inconsistency in story telling, or at least I can #8217;t think of a better answer.
Michael would have beaten Toby in a race if he didn't eat that much fettuccine alfredo because he is fast, he is very fast.

WRITING.TITLE: Should Firebolt be allowed on school tournaments?
WRITING.TEXT: I know money can #8217;t buy talent, and that in the end always the most talented group wins. I understand that brooms vary and that, of course, some kids have more money and can afford better brooms. But Firebolt is an *internetionally* good broom, used on World Cups by *professional* players. I simply cannot believe it does not influence the outcome of the match. For example, Wood dismisses Cho #8217;s Comet and says it is no match to Harry #8217;s firebolt. So we #8217;re in a situation where two seekers have insanely different chances of catching the snitch. What if a seeker notices the snitch first but the other one has a Firebolt? I just think that the school should impose some rule about brooms, like saying that nothing above Nimbus 2000 or below Cleansweeps is alowed, something like that.

Exactly. Truth be told, I haven #8217;t even seen Crimes of Grindelwald, but I heard the timeline was too frustrating for someone who has read the books. I did watch the first Fantastic Beasts movies and it was so disappointing. I can #8217;t remember any of the characters or what was even going on. The atmosphere just didn #8217;t seem right. You can #8217;t just give someone a wand and expect it to feel like it fits into Harry Potter universe. I think making those movies was a big mistake, and a complete waste of an oportunity.
Nice work

That would definitely be the best option. The school already has house elves who clean the whole castle for free. So that #8217;s a bunch of galleons saved right there. They could easily buy 28 solid brooms, and solve the whole inequality thing.
Don #8217;t forget 150 points taken away because they were walking around the school after dark...

I was thinking something along those lines... Like in football, if you had some sort of sneakers that enable you to run faster or something. If speed plays a role in sport, any additional help to achieve that speed should be monitored and, if necessary, prohibited. Especially if the only thing stopping you to achieve that speed is money.

Exactly, if anything, having a superior broom diminishes Harry #8217;s talent. I don #8217;t see why he had to have the best broom on the market every year (except 2nd). Yes, Firebolt was an important plot element, but I #8217;d still tone down it #8217;s greatness, in order for Harry to remain a great seeker without additional help.

I know that people come from different families, some are rich some aren #8217;t that #8217;s life. But in sports competitions those differences should be taken into account and reduced as much as possible which is why I think that Firebolt shouldn #8217;t be allowed.

No, but it #8217;s never too late to start caring about it. Also some inequalities are harder to sort out than others. Buying the same broom for every kid in Hogwarts that is on the house team is pretty easy.
Why are you the way that you are?

WRITING.TITLE: What are some of your favourite chapters?
WRITING.TEXT: Not necessarily your favourite chapter of all time, just the ones you really look foward to reading when you re-read the series. For example, I really like the chapter The House-elf Liberation Front in the GoF, because we get to see Dobby again, and we find out what the kitchens look like, and because of Ron #8217;s famous line #8221;Percy wouldn #8217;t recognize a joke if it danced naked in front of him wearing Dobby #8217;s tea-cosy. #8221; It #8217;s pre-Christmas time, and the atmosphere is really relaxed, and it #8217;s just a chapter I really like to read.
I couldn #8217;t agree more, they #8217;re my favourite part of every book too - everything leading up to Christmas, and the actual Christmas.
That whole chapter is so sad, it really gives a whole new dimension to Neville #8217;s character. It #8217;s too bad they didn #8217;t include it in the movie which is such a wasted opportunity.

WRITING.TITLE: Oh Neptune
Giving Harry his knife which opens any door required a lot of sacrifice on Sirius #8217; part.
WRITING.TEXT: I just realized that when Sirius gave Harry his knife for Christmas in GoF that he literally gave up on normal food in order for Harry to get a nice present. At that point he was hiding in the mountains near Hogsmead and I bet he used the knife to steal some food (if we consider that most shopowners secure their shops from being broken into with an Alohamora spell). So Sirius had to live off rats and starve and he nontheless gave the knife to Harry. It #8217;s such a sad moment actually but I never gave it much thought before now.

Yeah but didn #8217;t Sirius literally broke into someone #8217;s house to talk to Harry before the First Task? And didn #8217;t he collect newspaper in his dog form and walk around Hogsmead without fear of being caught? I was under the impression that he wasn #8217;t that scared of the Ministry in GoF because they looked for him in the south and were preoccupied with other things at the time (the Tournament, the World Cup, the dissapearance of Bertha and Barty Crouch). It was only in OotP that Malfoy noticed him and so the Ministry realized that he was in London. So while I understand your point, I still think that Sirius would have no problem with using the knife to get some food.
Yes, I think people forget about how much Harry was like a son to him.

Yes, I agree, it #8217;s probably because he hated Kreacher so much. I think that Sirius returned to Grimmauld Place at the end of GoF, because he had to, but he spent 2 years after he escaped wandering around.

Yeah, but Sleeping Draft is something only dragon keepers had at the time. Harry had two days until the task, I doubt he could #8217;ve brewed one, plus it would probably mean that he would have to break into Snape #8217;s office. Stealing/taking it from Charlie isn #8217;t an option either. Everyone would realize immediately and disqualify Harry and Charlie would get into trouble.

WRITING.TITLE: They called me a madman

WRITING.TEXT: It #8217;s probably a motorcycle. 1.) We see Hagrid at the beginning of a novel use it. I doubt JK thought about testrals so early on and those two are the only modes of transportation suitable for Hagrid if he wishes to fly (The Seven Potters being a good example). 2.) He says they #8217;ll go by a boat because he #8217;s not allowed to do magic now he #8217;s picked Harry up. And you need magic to drive the motorcycle. So Hagrid probably magicked the motorcycle back to mainland or something and picked it up later on. Any other explanation just doesn #8217;t make sense so early on in the series.

You #8217;re definitely right, I always think the same thing when I read the chapter when Harry Hermione Ron Luna Neville Ginny are fighting the Death Eathers in the Department of Misteries. They should just cast stupefy around and run. The only reason I can think of why they might cast something else is that maybe stupefy, if cast without enough determination, is not effective enought. Maybe they #8217;ll wake up too soon and be ok. So I guess in difficult situations they vary spells, because they can #8217;t stop and concentrate on just one effective spell?

I think Durmstrang is somewhere in northern Russia if I #8217;m not much mistaken? It covers the area of Eastern Europe, and so Krum who #8217;s Bulgarian attends it. The names of other students sound Russian and Karkaroff who is their headmaster sounds Russian too.

WRITING.TITLE: Well, that's awkward

WRITING.TEXT: That is a mistake that was later changed, in my editions Lily appears first and James second. Regarding Bertha, Voldemort did have some kind of form that enabled him to kill people, he killed Frank Bryce from an armchair but he was so little Harry couldn #8217;t see what he looked like. And he killed Bertha before Frank. We find out later on that he looked like a skinned child.

I knew right away that the bartender in the Hog #8217;s Head was Dumbledore #8217;s brother. He was kinda dodgy, and the pub smelled of goat. In GoF, Dumbledore said that his brother enchanted a goat or something like that. So that wasn #8217;t a big plot twist for me. The one that really surprised me was Snape being in love with Lily. I didn #8217;t see that one coming at all.

Thanks for making me feel smart! Idk I was a child when I figured that one out, I just connected the two times a goat was mentioned and didn #8217;t overthink it. If I was reading the books for the first time as an adult maybe I wouldn #8217;t figure it out.

WRITING.TITLE: Erin after she met Plop.
Is snapping someone #8217;s wand after they #8217;ve been expelled morally justified?
WRITING.TEXT: Harry performed underage magic in front of a muggle. Given how he was already warned against performing magic outside of school, the Ministry wanted to expel him and snap his wand in half. Ok, he did get away and was allowed to keep his wand, but that got me thinking. Why do they destroy someone #8217;s wand after they #8217;ve been expelled? Is it not enough that they don #8217;t get to finish their magical education? It already diminishes their chances of getting a good job. But also, if they don #8217;t get to keep their wands, they become complete outcasts, just like squibs. Which is worse, their whole magical education up until that point had become useless. Ok, Hagrid #8217;s wand was snapped in half because he was charged with the murder of another student. I can understand that. But any other fellony just doesn #8217;t seem big enough for the student to lose their wand. Plus, it probably affects the rise of a black market for wands. Students whose wands get confiscated will probably try and buy a new one, and so a whole illegal business is created. It just seems really unneccessary and completely wrong from a moral perspective.
Technically this isn #8217;t a plot hole. It just shows how wizards can be cruel, and how their laws sometimes don #8217;t make sense. Just like our laws.

Yeah I agree. like I said, it only causes illegal business to flourish. Wizarding laws can be medieval sometimes, and they don #8217;t really care about the outcasts (werewolves, squibs etc). This is one of those cases. I mean, we #8217;re talking about a world that allows prisoners to be mentally tortured by beings who are very difficult to control. But I still think it is well thought out.
Can you enroll in a different school if you #8217;ve been expelled? I always wondered about that

Wands are always dangerous. Take Crabbe and Goyle. Would they ever learn how to properly use one if they were to finish school? An uneducated wizard can do magic much better than those two, and if there wasn #8217;t a Voldemort uprising, Crabbe and Goyle would both finish Hogwarts.

WRITING.TITLE: MVP

WRITING.TEXT: I suppose that students develop their writing skills in a passive way, by reading different books. They do have to read a lot, and they always write essays for homework. I really hope that when teachers grade their essays that they correct grammar and spelling mistakes too. So instead of a deductive approach, teachers opt for an inductive approach, where they let the student come up with grammar rules themselves, through a process of trial and error.
*If doing the Scarn is gay, then I'm the biggest queer on Earth.*

WRITING.TITLE: Who is the best written character in the series?
WRITING.TEXT: Mine #8217;s probably Umbridge. Every detail about her character #8217;s just so perfect. Pointy teeth, pink outfits, high trembling girlish voice, desire to punish people who are out of order etc. She is one of the best villains in literature imho. Also the way she is first introduced gives me chills upon rereading. The way she lurkes in the shadows during Harry #8217;s hearing, and then comes to the light and straight up lies about the dementors and she was the one who sent them. JK Rowling really showed her writing abilities when creating Umbridge.

Yes I completely agree. The actress was good, but they could have made her more toad-like with makeup. She could have had a wig and a fat suit or something. I think her vile appearence emphasised her horrible personality in the books. The movie completely lost that aspect of her. But the fifth movie is when things just went wrong, I don #8217;t even want to get started...

I also love the fact that she was introduced in the very first chapter. She started caring about Harry immediately and we got to see her soft side. And so however strict she was in school, we knew that she is a very caring person actually.
Dumbledore is amazing yes! His way of talking is just so formal and yet so funny, I read some of his sentences a couple of times just to fully appreciate how witty he is
It taught me that if I have a choice between doing what #8217;s right and what #8217;s easy, to do the right thing no matter how hard it is.

WRITING.TITLE: I love this moment between Ron and Hermione
WRITING.TEXT: gt; #8217;Well #8217; he said, trying to sound as though he found the whole thing a joke. #8216;If you want to - er - what is it? #8217; - he checked Percy #8217;s letter - #8216;Oh yeah - #8220;sever ties with me, I swear I won #8217;t get violent. #8217; gt; #8217;Give it back #8217; said Ron, holding out his hand. #8216;He is - Ron said jerkily, tearing Percy #8217;s letter in half #8216;the world #8217;s - #8216; he tore it into quarters #8216;biggest- #8216; he tore it into eights #8216;git. #8217; He threw the pieces in the fire. #8216;Come on we #8217;ve got to get this finished sometime before dawn #8217;, he said briskly to Harry, pulling professor Sinistra #8217;s essay back towards him. gt; Hermione was loooking at Ron with an odd expression on her face. #8216;Oh give them here #8217; she said abruptly. Hermione #8217;s moments when her affection towards Ron show are some of my favourite moments in the series.
Yes you #8217;re definitely right, but in Percy #8217;s situation him coming and fighting Voldemort and apologizing to his family was definitely a Gryffindor move.
*Every day for eight years, I've brought pepper spray into this office to protect myself and my fellow employees. And every day, for eight years, people have laughed at me. Well, who's laughing now?*

I was thinking the same thing. She is the only teacher who taught Harry without a description of her physical appearance. I always wanted to know more about her and Astronomy in general. It would fit with the tone of the book, but I guess she was cut off from any real action in order for the plot to stay clear of big digresions.
love this!

WRITING.TITLE: I got this
Oh, I'm next

WRITING.TEXT: I think Krum is really underrated. They made him really stupid in the movies, like he #8217;s the type of guy who looks good but can #8217;t hold an intelligent conversation. He wouldn #8217;t have been chosen as a champion if that were true, and book Krum is really smart just also really shy, so he doesn #8217;t talk much, plus he #8217;s foreign so his English isn #8217;t that good. So I would say that movies didn #8217;t do him justice.

In order to be elected as a school champion you have to be both brave and intelligent. So I would say that that is enough book evidence to support tha claim that Krum is smart. The same goes for Fleur too, she #8217;s also smart, but since Harry doesn #8217;t spend much time with them we really don #8217;t get to see that. Krum #8217;s chemistry with Hermione is a completely different thing however. She doesn #8217;t seem that interested in him, and he #8217;s not really good with girls. I would never say they were a good couple because Hermione always liked Ron better. But the movie did this - they wanted to make an American teenage TV show move when a stupid jock falls for a pretty girl who #8217;s into books. Krum is far from being a stupid jock stereotype, like I said, he #8217;s just shy and foreign, but there is still so much more to him than the movies depicted.

WRITING.TITLE: I would love to get a better insight into McGonagall #8217;s and Snape #8217;s conversations
WRITING.TEXT: McGonagall #8217;s just so funny and sarcastic, I #8217;d love to see her bicker with Snape, but also see the two of them uniting in hating Lockhart and Umbridge together. Also they #8217;re both competitive and care about their House pride. I would read a book that #8217;s just the two of them in the staff room making snide remarks about one another.

WRITING.TITLE: Foreshadowing in the Order of the Phoenix
WRITING.TEXT: I just realized that the part where Ginny got the Snitch right out from under Cho #8217;s nose during the last match of the Quidditch season could be seen as a foreshadowing of her relationship with Harry. Order of the Phoenix is full of foreshadowing in general. Little details such as Sirius being the first to get up from the table where 13 people are sitting is another example of how his death was foreshadowed. It just goes to show how JK Rowling is an anazing writer. Do you guys have any other examples of foreshadowing in the series?
This is so good.
